question: Question_07_(b)
statement:
The line you gave as an answer in part
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH110/April_2011/Question_7_(a)}{
(a)} has an \emph{x}-intercept and a \emph{y}-intercept. Find these.
(They will be in terms of \emph{m}.)
sols:
Our line has a \emph{y}-intercept when $x = 0$. Plugging this into our
equation of the line, we get

\begin{align*}y = m(0) - m + 1 = -m + 1.\end{align*}

So our \emph{y}-intercept is $(0, -m + 1)$.

Similarly, our \emph{x}-intercept occurs when $y = 0$. Setting our
equation equal to zero and solving for $x$, we get

\begin{align*}0 = mx - m + 1\end{align*}

We see that if \emph{m=0}, then there is no \emph{x}-intercept (the line
is horizontal). Otherwise

\begin{align*}x = \frac{m-1}{m}\end{align*}

and our \emph{x}-intercept is $\left(\frac{m-1}{m} ,0\right)$.
hints:
What is the value of x at the y-intercept? The value of y at the
x-intercept? How can you use this information to find the other half of
the intercept?
